UNIVERSITY OF IOWA LIBRARY - DAY 67 A montage of Ray at the library: checking indices, reading old magazines, finding newspaper interviews on microfilm, s couring old anthologies, and taking copious notes. About whales and stuff. Then, he starts fooling around with a home computer, and gets hooked. Know what he does now? Annie shakes her head no.

direction.raw_text: . HARVARD STREET - DAY 82 In between a deli and a Kosher butcher shop, Ray finds a storefront with blacked-out windows. He enters an open hallway in which he sees the door to the storefront, as well as stairs to the apartments above it. There are half-a-dozen mail boxes on the wall. Ray checks the names. He smiles.

direction.raw_text: Ray turns to the storefront door. Instead of a buzzer there is a long wire with a weight on its end hanging from a hole at the top of the door. Next to the wire is a handwritten note taped to the door, which reads: "You better have a goddamn good reason for ringing this bell." Ray laughs. This guy is great. He pulls on the wire. On the other side of the door, a bell rings. Ray has to struggle to control his nervousness. He takes a breath. He hears footsteps inside, approaching the door. He cannot help but smile with delight at the thought of meeting one of his cultural heroes. The door opens. Terence Mann is menacingly huge. He glares at Ray and roars:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who the fuck are you???- Ray is momentarily taken aback, but he figures maybe the guy is joking, so he just smiles and plunges ahead.

A few workbenches have software and spread sheets strewn across them. In the back are a couple of personal computers. On a side wall there are book jackets and newspaper photos in cheap frames: pictures of Mann with Martin Luther King...with Bob Dylan...with Timothy Leary...rann being arrested at some demonstration.. .Mann at Woodstock... Mann's gruff voice pulls Ray's attention away from these relics.

Mann has returned to work, his back to the door. Ray enters the loft, his left hand in his jacket pocket. When he is halfway across the loft, he clears his throat. Mann spins around.

direction.raw_text: (O.S.) Oh no.

direction.raw_text: Nice going, Boze.

direction.raw_text: Okay. I don't really have a gun. So don't say anything to this guy, okay? I swear to God there's a reason we're supposed to be at this game. Mann gives him a "Give me a break" look. Ray sees the Policeman is getting out of his cruiser and walking towards them. Ray is desperate.

direction.raw_text: If I get arrested, the press'll be all over you, you'll have to appear in open court, you'll be the lead story on Entertainment Tonight, and your picture'll be on the front page of every tabloid in America. The Policeman knocks on Ray's window. He is young, fresh-scrubbed and earnest. Ray holds up one hand to him.

direction.raw_text: Ray. My...hostages call me Ray. Can I call you Terry? Sourly, Mann nods. Ray smiles and drives off.

direction.raw_text: (V.0.) And he smiled.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . MOTEL ROOM - NIGHT 125 It is later that same night, and Ray has been recounting his experience with Doc Graham to Mann, who appears quietly troubled.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And then I figured maybe we're not supposed to take him with us. So now I don't know why the hell we were supposed to come here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maybe it was to find out if one inning can change the world.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Did it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It did for these people. If he'd gotten a hit, he might've stayed there. (THEN) Your wife called before. She wants you to call her tonight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .RAY AND ANNIE'S BEDROOM - NIGHT 126 Annie is asleep. The phone rings, and the speed with which she picks it up suggests that her anxiety to get this phone call prevented her from sleeping very deeply.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray. (PAUSE) I asked the bank if we could miss a payment or two, and they told me they'd just sold the note on the farm to Mark and his partners. So they own the paper now, and he says if we don't sell to them, they'll foreclose. Ray, we don't have the money.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . MOTEL ROOM - NIGHT 127 Ray holds the phone, pained.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay, look. They can't foreclose for thirty days, or something like that. I've got to take Terry back to Boston first, so it'll be --- MANN No. Ray looks over at Mann.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm going to Iowa with you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We're coming home.-
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - MORNING 128 Ray drives with purpose and speed. Mann looks relaxed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hell, I couldn't quit now. I've got see this ballpark.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not everybody can see it. You might not.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll give it a try. As they turn onto the highway near the lake, a Teenager with a dufflebag appears on the side of the road, his arm raised in. a hitchhiker's stance. Ray pulls the car over to the side of the road.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - - - CONTINUED 128 RAY I need all the karma I can get right now. The car stops, and the Teenager runs for it. He tosses his dufflebag in the backseat and squeezes in after it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thanks. You're the first car by. I didn't expect to get a lift so soon. Ray starts the car back onto the highway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How far are you going?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How far are you going?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Iowa.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, if it's okay with you, I'll ride along for a while. I play baseball. Ray and Mann exchange brief smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm looking for a place to play, and I heard that all through the Midwest, towns have teams, and in some places they'll find you a day job so you can play ball nights and weekends.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is your lucky day, kid. We're going someplace kind of like that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All right!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm Ray Kinsella, this is Terry Mann.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hi. I'm Archie Graham. Mann and Ray just look at each other. And the little Datsun heads off down the highway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CAR - NIGHT Archie sleeps in the backseat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm dying to ask him if he has a nickname.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't. He didn't get it till he was in the minors.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maybe we can give it to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Funny, the way he described towns, finding you a job so you can play on their team...they haven't done that for years. My Dad did that for a while. But that was in the Twenties.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What happened to your father?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He never made it as ball player, so he tried to get his son to make it for him. By the time I was ten, playing baseball got to be like eating vegetables or taking out the garbage, so when I was fourteen, I started to refuse. Can you believe that? An American boy refusing to have a catch with his father.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why at fourteen?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's when I read The Boat Rocker, by Terence Mann.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh God.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I never played catch with him again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: See, that's the kind of crap people are always trying to lay on me. It's not my fault you wouldn't play catch with your father!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know. Anyway, when I was seventeen, we had a big fight, I packed my things, said something awful, and left. After a while I wanted to come home, but I didn't know how. I made it back for the funeral.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What was the awful thing you said?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I said I could never respect a man whose hero was a criminal.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who was his hero?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Shoeless Joe Jackson. Mann considers this all very carefully.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You knew he wasn't a criminal. Ray nods.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then why'd you say it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I was seventeen. Mann nods with growing understanding.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So this is your penance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know. I can't bring my father back..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .so the least you can do is bring back his hero. Ray nods.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well now we know what everybody's purpose here is...except mine. Ray looks at him. He hadn't thought of that. After a few moments Ray points to something in the distance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Something down the road, in the midst of all this flat farmland, is glowing in the night. It is an illuminated baseball diamond in a cornfield.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray turns the Datsun into the long driveway and, with a rumble, crosses the metal cattle guard that keeps livestock from escaping to the roadway. He eases the car to a stop in front of the house, and as the three men unfold themselves from the car, Karin bolts from the back door of the house, a blur of white blouse and pink pedal pushers. She flings herself into Ray's arms, and hugs his neck in unrestrained joy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Daddy! Then Annie appears too. They kiss while Mann and Archie wait to be introduced. Finally, Mann clears his throat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Karin, Annie... This is Terence Mann
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Terry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hiya Terry. Annie steps forward, wining some curls from her eyes with ahand that has recently been immersed in flour'. She smiles, wipes the hand on the thigh of her jeans, and shakes his hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Welcome.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And this young fellow is Moon -- uh, Archie Graham. Karin and Annie shake his hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's come to practice with the team.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He'll be able to do more than just practice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What does that mean?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come on. They walk towards the field.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let's enjoy this place while we still have it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BASEBALL FIELD - NIGHT 132 Ray and Annie walk silently with their arms around each other as they lead Mann, Archie and Karin to the bleachers. Mann's eyes widen as several of the players shout greetings to Ray.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hi, Ray, welcome back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thanks, Joe. Good to see you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh my Lord.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's Shoeless Joe Jackson!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well of course it is.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've seen pictures. Those are the White Sox!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You mean you still didn't believe me?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I thought I did, but... Oh my Lord. They have reached the foul line where Shoeless Joe waits for them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Terry, I'd like you to meet Joe Jackson. Joe, this is Terry Mann. Mann and Jackson shake hands.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's a pleasure to meet you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pleasure's mine. (TO RAY) Ray, I hope you don't mind, but we got tired of just having practices, so we brought another team out with us so we could have some real games. He points to the visitors' bench, and, indeed, there are a dozen or so more old-time baseball players in old-time baseball uniforms.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't mind. Where'd they come from?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where'd we come from. Man, you wouldn't believe how many guys wanted to play here. We had to beat 'em off with a stick.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey, that's Mel Ott. And Carl Hubbell. Those are the New York Giants!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: With a couple of Cardinals and A's thrown in for good measure. Ty Cobb wanted to play, but none of us could stand the sonofabitch when we were alive, so we told him to stuff it. (TO ARCHIE) Hey, are you Graham?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes sir. Ray and Mann are astonished that Shoeless Joe knows who Archie is.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What the hell you doing on the sidelines? You came here to play ball, didn't you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes sir.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Go warm up!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes sir! Archie quickly scampers down the bleachers, onto the field, shakes Joe's hand, and runs to the dugout.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Unbelievable.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's more than that. It's perfect.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The White Sox are in the field, the Giants at bat. A Giant hitter bunts, and the runner on second takes third despite a close throw. Mann, Ray, Karin and Annie are in the stands, Mann keeping score.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Does he get a hit for that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Karin?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Um, no. The batter was trying to sacrifice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So how do you score it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fielder's choice?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Very good.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mann is impressed. He lifts Karin up from her seat on the row below them, and places her next to him to help him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You better sit here. Karin beams. Ray taps Mann and points to the plate.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look. Archie Graham -- now wearing a Giant's uniform -- drops one of the two bats he has been swinging in the on-deck circle, and advances on the plate, slashing the air with a brand-new bat the color of vanilla ice cream. He plants himself in the batter's b.ox, then cocks the bat, the top end of it trembling as if he were stirring something, and waits for the pitch.' The pitcher looks in for his signs. Archie stares back. As the pitcher goes into his windup, Archie winks at him. There is a moment of confusion and then anger on the pitcher's face, and when the ball speeds to the plate it is aimed right at Archie's head. He dives out of the way and hits the dirt hard. The Catcher chuckles through his mask.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good thing for you that wasn't his fastball. Archie digs in again at the plate, but backs up just a little. Now his look to the pitcher is one of determination.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come on, let's see your fastball. The pitcher smiles, winds up and throws. Very fast. And right at Archie's chin. Again, he has to dive out of the way. This time, however, he gets right up and immediately appeals to the Umpire.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey, ump, how about a warning?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sure. Watch out-you don't get killed. Both benches laugh at that. Archie holds up his hands to call time, and steps out of the batter's box. The on-deck batter, Mel Ott, comes over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay, kid, first two were high and tight, where do you think the next one's going to be?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Either-low and away, or in my ear.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He don't want to load the bases. Look for low and away. Archie nods and starts to walk back to the plate.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But watch out for 'in your ear.' Archie takes his place in the batter's box again. He still looks determined, but a little less cocky. The next pitch is a curve that looks as if it's heading right for him. But he holds his ground, and when the ball breaks down and away, he steps in, snaps the bat forward, and hits it. The ball sails in a high arc to right center. The center fielder backs up a couple of steps, lopes a few strides to his left, and makes the catch. Archie is out, but the runner on third tags up and scores. As Archie curls across the diamond from the first baseline to the Giants' bench, he hears cheering. In the stands, Ray, Annie, Karin and Mann are giving him a standing ovation. In return, he touches the brim of his cap, a ballplayer's cool response to adulation.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look at that. Mr. Cool. But when Archie gets to the bench, he can't contain himself anymore. He leaps up and lets out a cheer of pure joy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - LATER 134 The game has ended, and players are rough-housing and joking as they slowly make their way to the door in the outfield fence. Ray and Mann are talking to some of the players over the fence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where do you go when you walk through that door? What do you do?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We sleep.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And wait.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We dream.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You can't leave the field any other way, can you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not if we want to come back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'd love to go with you sometime. The silence that follows is long and ominous.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'd like to see what's out there. There is still no response.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll take that as a no for now. He spots Archie jogging off the field.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey, slugger, congratulations! Archie jogs over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thanks. I can't stop shaking I'm so happy. 'Course, I would've liked a base hit...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But you got a RBI!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I sure did, didn't I?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A rookie's luck! They all laugh at that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well come on, this calls for a drink.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Archie hesitates.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can't. I'm... He motions with his head toward the other players disappearing through the outfield door. Ray nods understandingly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good game, Archie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thanks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good night, kid. Ray, Karin, Annie and Mann watch Archie jog towards the rest of the players. When he reaches the fence, he turns back to them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Kinsella? Ray turns toward him. Archie looks as if he knows more than he's saying.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you for bringing me here. I couldn't have wished for anything more. Ray recognizes there may be more behind those words than just a teenager's pleasure. But he decides not to ask any questions.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know. You're welcome. Archie runs through the door in the fence and vanishes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . KITCHEN - MORNING 135 Mann and Karin eat their country breakfasts at one and of the table, while at the other end, Annie and Ray sit in front of the bank books, ledgers, and the sheaf of bills puffed up around the paper spike.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Once we fell behind in the payments, the full amount of the mortgage became due.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And they own the paper, so they have the legal right to foreclose.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Unless we sell.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Either way we lose the farm. Maybe we can make it a condition of the sale that they keep the field up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Forget it. They're buying up single farms all around us, make it one big farm. First thing they'll do is plow under your field. Ray just sits there, letting that sink in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . FARM - DAY 1.36 Ray and Mann walking.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't have a lot of money, Ray, but maybe I could pitch in a little.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fine. You can put in twenty bucks for groceries.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's not what I meant. Maybe the reason you were supposed to find me was so I could help you with this.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: More likely it's that you're supposed to start writing again. About this.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't change the subject.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You promise to publish and I'll let you chip in from your royalties. Mann's expression suddenly turns to one of indignation.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: One thing has nothing to do with the other.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not sure I agree with that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're not only stubborn, you're stupid.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That I won't argue with. Annie emerges from the house and calls to Ray.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Honey, that was Mark. He's coming tonight. He needs a decision tonight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Again, it's J,oe Jackson's Chicago White Sox against the New York Giants, now featuring rookie Archie Graham. In the stands, Mann keeps score, Karin munches on a hot dog, and Annie and Ray snuggle together to watch the game.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Everything is so perfect here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Whatever I have to do to save this place, I'll do.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know. Suddenly, Ray snaps his head to the side, as one does to pick up a-distant sound.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's here. They look and see Mark's car heading up the gravel lane. He parks the car at the edge of the field, and the game stops as he walks right across it, completely mindless of the players. Since he doesn't see any of them, a few actually have to move out of his way. He approaches the bottom of the bleachers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're interrupting the game, . Mark.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mark shakes his head sadly at the thought that these otherwise sensible relations have lost their minds.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray, it's time'to put away our little fantasies and come down to earth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's not a fantasy, Mark. They're real. Mark obviously do.esn't see anyone on the field.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who's real?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Shoeless Joe Jackson. The White Sox. The Giants. (TO MANN) He can't see any of it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And who's that? Babe Ruth? Ray smiles, savoring the moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As a matter of fact, it's Terence Mann.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ah, how do you? I'm Michael Jackson. (TO RAY) Ray, we have to settle this thing right now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not selling you my home.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You have no money, you've got a stack of bills to choke a pig, and come fall, you've got no crop to sell. But I have a deal to offer you that will allow you to stay on this land. This has Ray's attention. Mark climbs the bleachers to stand closer to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Daddy, we don't have to sell the farm. But no one pays her any attention. All eyes are on Mark.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let us buy you out, and we'll leave the house. You can live in it rent free as long as you want.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What about the baseball field?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you realize what this land is worth?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Over $2200 an acre.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then you must realize we cannot keep a useless baseball diamond in the middle of rich farmland.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No deal, Mark. We're staying.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We don't have to go.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're virtually bankrupt, and I'm offering you a way to keep your home because I love my sister! I've got partners who don't give a damn about you, and they're ready to foreclose right now!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Daddy, we don't have to sell the farm.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Karin, please!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wait. They all turn to Karin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: People will come.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What people, sweetheart?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: From all over. They'll just decide to take a vacation, see, and they'll come to Iowa City, and they'll think it's really boring, so they'll take a drive. And they'll drive down our road, and they'll see the lights and they'll think it's really pretty. Ray, Annie, and Mann listen with wonder, to this vision.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So, the people in the cars? They'll drive up and they'll want to pay us, like buying a ticket. Mark looks at them all as if they're crazy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're not listening to this seriously, are you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why would anybody pay money to come here? Karin looks at her Uncle mark as if he were a simpleton.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: To watch the game. And it'll be just like when they were little kids a long time ago, and it was summertime, and they'll watch the game and .remember what it was like. Ray and Annie couldn't be prouder of their daughter than they are right now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What the hell is she talking about?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She's talking about people seeing their memories... touching their past.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: People will come.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It'll be like one of those tiny, French restaurants that have no sign. You find it by instinct. They'll be drawn.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay, this is all fascinating, but the fact remains that you don't have the money to bring the mortgage up to date, so you still have to sell. I'm sorry, but you have no choice. He produces a document and hands it to Ray with a pen. Ray looks at it. He doesn't know what to do.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray... Ray looks at Mann.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .38 speaks now as he has not spoken for many years: as Terence Mann, master of words, spellbinder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: People will come, Ray. They'll come to Iowa for reasons they can't even fathom. They'll turn up your driveway, not knowing for sure why they're doing it, and arrive at your door, innocent as children, longing for the past. 'Of course we won't mind if you look around,' you'll say. 'It's only twenty dollars per person.' And they'll pass over the money without even looking at it. For it is money they have, and peace they lack.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pushes the papers. forward.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just sign the papers, Ray.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: is not one to give up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They'll walk out to the bleachers and sit in shirtsleeves in the perfect evening, or they'll find they have reserved seats somewhere in the grandstand or along one of the baselines
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: wherever they sat when they were children and cheered their heroes. They'll watch the game, and it will be as if they'd dipped themselves in magic waters. The memories will be so thick they'll have to brush them away from their faces.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Spellbound, Ray has put the papers down. Mark picks them up again. He is battling Mann for Ray's attention.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Listen to me. Tomorrow morning, when the bank opens, they will foreclose.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: People will come, Ray.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're broke, Ray. Sell now or lose everything.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The one constant through all the years, Ray, has been baseball. America has rolled by like an`army of steamrollers. It's been erased like a blackboard, rebuilt, and erased again. But baseball has marked the time. This field, this game... it's a piece of our past. It reminds us of all that once was good. And that could be again. People will come. People will most definitely come. Mann has moved everyone (but Mark) with the beauty of his words, and the passion in his.voice. Behind him, the assembled ballplayers respectfully applaud.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That was beautiful... The other players nod, also teary-eyed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .fuckin' beautiful. The players on either side of him jab his ribs with their elbows, but Mann, Ray and Annie laugh with pleasure.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray. You will lose everything and you will be evicted. Ray looks at the paper with dread. He looks at Shoeless Joe and the players. He looks at his family. Then he turns back to Mark. It's decision time.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not signing. Mark shakes his head sadly. Annie hugs Ray. The players breathe a great sigh of relief. Mann smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray... Ray looks up at Mann, who, with a gentle tilt of the head, directs Ray's attention to the house. Ray looks behind him toward the house.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - CARS 142 have parked in front of the house. More are coming quietly down the driveway. Dozens of cars. Cars with out-of-state license plates. Some people,have gotten out of their cars and wait patiently. One or two families sit on their hoods, or have set up picnic dinners on their station wagons' tailgates.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray, Annie, Karin and Mann are deeply happy -- but not terribly surprised -- to see these people.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They're he-re. Mark looks at the house and then back at Ray.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who's here?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (with an edge) You don't see those cars? All those people?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't do this, you son of a bitch! There's no cars, no people...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Uncle Mark, I can see them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We all can.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're crazy. You're all bat-shit crazy!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Watch your language, Mark.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You build a baseball field in the middle of nowhere, you sit around here and stare at nothing --- KARIN It's not nothing. Mark grabs Karin's arm and pulls her to her feet as if she were "Exhibit A."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And you've turned your daughter into a goddamn moron!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Get your hands off her. Ray rises threateningly, and Mark turns toward him. In so doing, he twists little Karin off balance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm trying to help you, goddamnit! In that split second, they hear a strangled gasp, and see Karin falling forward from the top row of the bleachers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Karin!!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Her hot dog flies off, the bun and wiener separating in midair. One small sandal bounces end over end and lands at the foot of the bleacher. It takes forever for her body to come down with a sickening thud on the hard green boards of one of the bottom rows.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: rush down to where she lies, face up. Ray is first, but he does not know what to do. Annie and Mann hover. Mark is horror-stricken, but no one knows what to do.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh my God, I'm sorry...Annie...I didn't mean to... Karin is unconscious, and seems to be fighting for breath. Ray and Annie's eyes meet in anguish.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Should we move her?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Get the car.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: springs for the house. The tourists by their cars watch quietly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is there a doctor? A nurse? Any of you? They sadly shake their heads no. Annie races inside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Most of the White Sox players stand by the left field fence, staring silently.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How long?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Its a twenty-minute drive. Mann winces. He knows that could be fatal. Ray kneels by Karin. Her nose and one side of her face have been scraped by the fall. Blood starts to trickle from her nose, across her cheek and down her neck. She is becoming bluer and her cough is faint, as though she is in another room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mark takes off his $300 pale-green velvet corduroy jacket and is wordlessly holding it out to Ray. Ray takes the jacket and covers Karin gently. Karin is getting paler, bluer, and her breathing more strained and distant.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Karin... Then, without reason, Ray slowly turns toward the field. The White Sox stand near him by the fence, the Giants stay around their bench. All except one: young Archie Graham.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: has noticed the'commotion in the bleachers, and he starts to lope across the field.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Annie has pulled the car over and honks. Ray holds up his hand to her to wait. His eyes are on young Archie Graham.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .50 As Graham gets closer, his features begin to change, and his step slows. He reaches the end of the fence -- around which no player can pass
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: and when he emerges from the shadows on the bleachers side, he is no longer young Moonlight Graham, the ballplayer of long ago...but Doc Graham, the old man from Chisholm, Minnesota. His baseball glove has turned into a black doctor's bag.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: as Doc Graham approaches.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What have we got here?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She fell. Doc kneels beside her and instantly knows what is wrong.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This child's choking to death.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He picks her up with one hand under her shoulders and the other under her knees, seats himself on the bleachers, and turns her face down. Supporting her chest with one hand, he delivers a series of sharp blows between her shoulder blades with the heel of his other hand. Annie honks again. Ray waves her to him. Mark cannot believe what he is seeing. Suddenly, Karin's diaphragm expands as she sucks in air. Doc reaches around and pries her mouth open, releasing a sizable piece of hog dog and bun. As he turns her over, we can see the blueness disappearing from her face as she continues to breathe deeply. Doc peels back each eyelid in turn, stares at the pupil for a few seconds, and lets the eye close.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She's okay. I don't think the fall really hurt her, just the dog in her throat. She'll be coming around in a minute or two.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you, Doc. Doc looks deeply into Ray's eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, son. Thank you. It just now sinking for Ray what-Doc Graham has sacrificed to save the child. Ray looks to the field, and then back at the Doctor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: 'Oh, my God, you can't go back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's okay... (NODS KNOWINGLY) It's okay.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mark is slack-jawed. He has seen something magical happen and cannot explain it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I saw...A11 of a sudden this kid runs off the field and turns.into...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He looks questioningly at Annie. She smiles reassuringly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's hope for you yet, Mark.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Doc Graham stands, and picks up his black bag.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, I best be getting back home before Alicia starts to thinking I've got a girlfriend. He walks around the edge of the fence, and heads for the outfield door. The players respectfully make way for him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good work, Doc.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Way to go, Doc.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thanks, boys. Win one for me, someday, will you? He passes them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hev rookie! Doc Graham turns.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You were good. Only now do Doc Graham's eyes shine with tears. He smiles, and disappears through the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Karin is coming to, Ray and Annie by her side. Some of the players start to gather up their equipment. Shoeless Joe calls to Ray.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We're gonna call it a night. We'll see you tomorrow.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good night. Joe starts to trot off the field, then he stops and turns back to the bleachers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey! You wanna come with us? Ray's jaw drops.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You mean it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not you. (points to Mann) Him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Him?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come with you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Out there.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What is out there?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come find out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wait a second. Why him? Shoeless Joe and the other players wait for Mann to join them, ignoring Ray's question.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I built this field! You wouldn't be here if it weren't for me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray, for God's sake, I'm unattached. You've got a family. This takes Ray down a peg or two.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But I want to know what's out there! I want to see it!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's a reason they chose me, just as there was a reason they chose you to find me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh yeah? Why?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Because, you big jerk, I gave that interview.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What interview?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The one about Ebbets Field. The one that charged you up and sent you all the way to Boston to find me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then you lied to me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You were kidnapping me at the time, you asshole! Think of it, Ray: maybe there's an Ebbets Field still floating around out there somewhere. And maybe I'll get to sit in the stands, and watch a twenty-year-old kid with a smooth face and kinky hair try out for the 1948 Dodgers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to Shoeless Joe) So I do all the work, and all I get is to see everybody else's dreams come true. Is that it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What are you saying, Ray?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm saying I'm happy for you, and I'm happy for him, but after all this what's in it L for me?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is that why you did this? For-you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's something out there for me, Ray. And what a story it'll make: a man being able to touch the perfect dream.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then you'll write about it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You bet I will. Annie walks Karin over. Ray bends down to Karin's face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How you feeling, honey?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stupid. Ray laughs and hugs her. He looks up at Annie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Terry's been invited to go-with the players.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You mean 'out'?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Doo-doo-doo-doo. Be careful. She smiles brightly and gives Mann a kiss on the cheek. Mann shakes Ray's hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I want a full description.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: -You take care of this family, Ray. Mann joins several of the White Sox as they leave the field.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: is absolutely dumbfounded as'he sees the players fade out upon walking through the outfield gate. He turns to Annie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He just... Where'd he...?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .5 CONTINUED 155 ANNIE You go inside and lie down. I'll explain later. Mark walks off toward the people in their cars outside the house.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where'd all these people come from...?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .56 Only a few players are left on the field.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We're keeping this field.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You bet your ass we are. Ray realizes Shoeless Joe is staring at him, with a shit-eating grin on his face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What.. Shoeless Joe just keeps smiling.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What're you grinning at, you ghost?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: 'If you build it... He nods toward where the catcher is taking off his gear at home plate.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .he will come.' Ray looks at the Catcher. The hairs on the back of his neck begin to stand up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, my God.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What is it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Its my father.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: has taken off his mask. He is in his early twenties. He is in the same pose as the photo we saw in the prologue.
direction.name: direction
